Path Homotopy Invariants and their Application to Optimal Trajectory Planning

Subhrajit Bhattacharya
Department of Mechanical Engineering
and Mechanics, Lehigh University, PA.
E-mail: sub216@lehigh.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Robert Ghrist
Department of Mathematics,
University of Pennsylvania, PA.
E-mail: ghrist@math.upenn.edu
Abstract

We consider the problem of optimal path planning in different homotopy classes in a given environment. Though important in robotics applications, path-planning with reasoning about homotopy classes of trajectories has typically focused on subsets of the Euclidean plane in the robotics literature. The problem of finding optimal trajectories in different homotopy classes in more general configuration spaces (or even characterizing the homotopy classes of such trajectories) can be difficult. In this paper we propose automated solutions to this problem in several general classes of configuration spaces by constructing presentations of fundamental groups and giving algorithms for solving the word problem in such groups. We present explicit results that apply to knot and link complements in 3-space, discuss how to extend to cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces of arbitrary dimension, and also present results in the coordination space of robots navigating on an Euclidean plane. 111Parts of this paper has appeared in the proceedings of the IMA Conference on Mathematics of Robotics (IMAMR), 2015.

1 Introduction

In the context of robot motion planning, one often encounters problems requiring optimal trajectories (paths) in different homotopy classes. For example, consideration of homotopy classes is vital in planning trajectories for robot teams separating/caging and transporting objects using a flexible cableÂ (Bhattacharya etÂ al., 2015), or in planning optimal trajectories for robots that are tethered to a base using a fixed-length flexible cableÂ (Kim etÂ al., 2014), or in human-robot collaborative exploration problems in context of search-and-rescue missionsÂ (Govindarajan etÂ al., 2014). This paper addresses the problem of optimal path planning with homotopy class as the optimization constraint.

There is, certainly, a large literature on minimal path-planning in computational geometry (for a brief sampling and overview, see (Mitchell and Sharir, 2004)). The topology of a configuration space plays a key role in solving path-planning problems. To that end, the study of the topological invariants of robot configuration spaces and the properties of motion planning problems in such configuration spaces is not newÂ (Farber, 2001; Costa and Farber, 2010; Farber etÂ al., 2006; Cohen and Pruidze, 2007). However, most of this body of research has primarily focused on deduction of topological invariants of configuration/coordination spaces, addressed existence questions, have studied properties of the motion planning problem itself, but do not explicitly implement algorithms for finding optimal paths in configuration spaces of robots. Classification of paths based on homotopy has also been studied in the robotics literature in two-dimensional planar workspaces using geometric methods (Grigoriev and Slissenko, 1998; Hershberger and Snoeyink, 1991), probabilistic road-map construction (Schmitzberger etÂ al., 2002) techniques and triangulation-based path planning (Demyen and Buro, 2006). While in a planar configuration space such methods can be used for determining whether or not two trajectories belong to the same homotopy class, efficient planning for least cost trajectories with homotopy class constraints is difficult using such representations even in 222-dimensions. To that end in prior work we developed a graph search-based method for computing shortest paths in different homology classes in 222, 333 and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces with obstaclesÂ (Bhattacharya etÂ al., 2012, 2013), and in different homotopy classes in planar configuration spaces with obstaclesÂ (Bhattacharya etÂ al., 2015).

Of course, since the problem of computing shortest paths (even for a 3-d simply-connected polygonal domain) is NP-hard (Canny and Reif, 1987), we must restrict attention to subclasses of spaces, even when using homotopy path constraints. In particular, we construct a discrete graph representation of a configuration space and thus reduce the problem to shortest path computation on the graph. This representation, along with path homotopy invariants of the configuration space, allows us to compute shortest paths in different homotopy classes using graph search-based path planning algorithms.

This paper focuses on computation of optimal paths in different homotopy classes in two interesting and completely different types of configuration spaces: (1) knot and link complements in 3-d; and (2) cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006). Compared to our prior conference publicationÂ (Bhattacharya and Ghrist, 2015), in this paper we have (i) provided a rigorous Proposition on the presentation of the fundamental group of knot/link complements in 333-d and hence the justification behind the proposed homotopy invariants in such spaces, (ii) have provided an explicit presentation of the fundamental group of cylindrically deleted coordination space for robots navigating on a plane, and (iii) hence have demonstrated through simulation the problem of optimal path computation in different homotopy classes for three robots navigating on a simple planar domain.

2 Configuration Spaces with Free Fundamental Groups

Free Group and Free Product of Groups: A free group over a set of letters/symbols is the group whose elements consists of all words constructed out of the letters and their formal inverses, with identity element being the empty word, and the group operation being word concatenation (with any letter juxtaposed with its inverse reducing to the identity)Â (Scott and Scott, 1964). Given two groups, GğºG and Hğ»H, the free product of the groups is the group of words that can be constructed with all the elements of the groups as the letters. The free product is thus written as Gâˆ—H={g1â€‹h1â€‹g2â€‹h2â€‹â‹¯|giâˆˆG,hiâˆˆH}ğºğ»conditional-setsubscriptğ‘”1subscriptâ„1subscriptğ‘”2subscriptâ„2â‹¯formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğºsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ»G*H=\{g_{1}h_{1}g_{2}h_{2}\cdots|g_{i}\in G,h_{i}\in H\}.

2.4 Simple Extension to (â„3âˆ’ğ’ª)superscriptâ„3ğ’ª(\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O}) with Unlinked Unknotted Obstacles

The construction described in SectionÂ 2.2 can be easily extended to the 333-dimensional Euclidean space punctured by a finite number of un-knotted and un-linked toroidal (possibly of multi-genus) obstacles. Instead of â€œraysâ€, in this case the Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s are 222-dimensional sub-manifolds that satisfy the conditions in PropositionÂ 1, with a letter, uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} (or uiâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1u_{i}^{-1}), being inserted in hâ€‹(Î³)â„ğ›¾h(\gamma) every time the curve, Î³ğ›¾\gamma, crosses/intersects a Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}. This is illustrated in FiguresÂ 2(a) and 2(b).

However, a little investigation makes it obvious that such 222-dimensional sub-manifolds cannot always be constructed when the obstacle are knotted or linked (FigureÂ 2(c)). One can indeed construct surfaces (e.g. Seifert surfaces) satisfying some of the properties, but not all.

2.5 Application to Graph Search-based Path Planning

Using the homotopy invariants described in the previous sub-section, we describe a graph construction for use in search-based path planning for computing optimal (in the graph) trajectories in different homotopy classes. Suppose G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a discrete graph representation of a configuration space, Xğ‘‹X. That is, Vğ‘‰V, is a set of points (vertices) sampled from Xğ‘‹X, and for any two neighboring points x1,x2âˆˆVsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘‰x_{1},x_{2}\in V (where neighbors are typically determined by a distance threshold), there exists an edge (x1,x2)âˆˆEsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2ğ¸(x_{1},x_{2})\in E. 222We assume that the discretization is such that corresponding to every homotopy class in the configuration space there exists at least one path in the graph that successfully captures/represents that homotopy class. This is true if the sampling of the vertices is sufficiently dense in Xğ‘‹X, and the edge connecting neighboring vertices is the shortest path (with respect to the metric of the underlying space) connecting those points in Xğ‘‹X. We assume xsâˆˆVsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘‰x_{s}\in V.

We first fix the set of sub-manifolds {U1,U2,â‹¯,Un}subscriptğ‘ˆ1subscriptğ‘ˆ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘›\{U_{1},U_{2},\cdots,U_{n}\} as described earlier. Now, given a discrete graph representation of the configuration space, G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E), we construct an hâ„h-augmented graph, Gh=(Vh,Eh)subscriptğºâ„subscriptğ‘‰â„subscriptğ¸â„G_{h}=(V_{h},E_{h}), which is essentially a lift of GğºG into the universal covering space of Xğ‘‹XÂ (Hatcher, 2001). The construction of such augmented graphs has been described in our prior workÂ (Bhattacharya etÂ al., 2015; Kim etÂ al., 2014; Govindarajan etÂ al., 2014), and the explicit construction of Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h} can be described as follows:

    Vertices in Vhsubscriptğ‘‰â„V_{h} are tuples of the form (x,w)ğ‘¥ğ‘¤(x,w), where xâˆˆVğ‘¥ğ‘‰x\in V and wğ‘¤w is a word made out of letters uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} and uiâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1u_{i}^{-1}.

    (xs,â€œâ€‹â€)âˆˆVhsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ â€œâ€subscriptğ‘‰â„(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''})\in V_{h}.

  3. iii.

    For every edge [x1,x2]âˆˆEsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2ğ¸[x_{1},x_{2}]\in E and every vertex (x1,w)âˆˆVhsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘‰â„(x_{1},w)\in V_{h}, there exists an edge [(x1,w),(x2,wâˆ˜hâ€‹(x1â€‹x2â†’))]âˆˆEhsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘¤â„â†’subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ¸â„[(x_{1},w),(x_{2},w\circ h(\overrightarrow{x_{1}x_{2}}))]\in E_{h}, where x1â€‹x2â†’â†’subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2\overrightarrow{x_{1}x_{2}} denotes the directed curve that constitutes the edge [x1,x2]subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2[x_{1},x_{2}].

  4. iv.

    The length/cost of an edge in Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h} is same as its projection in GğºG: CGhâ€‹([(x1,w1),(x2,w2)])=CGâ€‹([x1,x2])subscriptğ¶subscriptğºâ„subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ¶ğºsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2C_{G_{h}}\left([(x_{1},w_{1}),(x_{2},w_{2})]\right)=C_{G}([x_{1},x_{2}]).

The item â€˜i.â€™ is just a qualitative description of the vertices in Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h}. Item â€˜ii.â€™ describes one particular vertex in Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h}, and using that, item â€˜iii.â€™ describes an incremental construction of the entire graph Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h}. The topology of Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h} can be described as a lift of GğºG into the universal covering space, X~~ğ‘‹\widetilde{X}, of Xğ‘‹X, and is illustrated in FigureÂ 3 for a uniform cylindrically discretized space with a single disk-shaped obstacle.

Such an incremental construction is well-suited for use in graph search algorithms such as Dijkstraâ€™s or A*Â (Cormen etÂ al., 2001), in which one initiates an open set using the start vertex (in item ii.), and then gradually expands vertices, generating only the neighbors at every expansion (the recipe for which is given by item â€˜iii.â€™). Executing a search (Dijkstraâ€™s/A*) in Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h} from (xs,â€œâ€‹â€)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ â€œâ€(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''}) to vertices of the form (xe,âˆ—)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘’(x_{e},*) (where â€˜âˆ—*â€™ denotes any word), and projecting it back to GğºG, gives us optimal trajectories in GğºG that belong to different homotopy classes. FigureÂ 4(a) shows 555 such optimal trajectories in the graph, connecting a given start and goal vertex, where GğºG was constructed by an uniform hexagonal discretization of the planar configuration space. One can then employ a simple curve shortening algorithmÂ (Kim etÂ al., 2014) to obtain ones more optimal than the ones restricted to GğºG (FigureÂ 4(b)). Similarly, shortest trajectories connecting xssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ x_{s} and xesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘’x_{e} can be obtained in 333-dimensional configuration spaces with free fundamental group (e.g., FigureÂ 4(d), showing 444 paths connecting two fixed points in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3} with two un-linked toroidal obstacles).

3 Knot and Link Complements

As described earlier, when the obstacle set in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3} consists of knots and links, it is in general not possible to find the sub-manifolds UiâŠ‚(â„3âˆ’ğ’ª)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–superscriptâ„3ğ’ªU_{i}\subset(\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O}) as required by PropositionÂ 1. However, thankfully we have more generalized versions of the Van Kampen theorem at our disposal that lets us extend the proposed methodology to such spaces. We first illustrate the generalization in â„3âˆ’ğ’ªsuperscriptâ„3ğ’ª\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O} using knot/link diagrams.

3.1 Dehn Presentation of Fundamental Group of Knot/Link Complements

For simplicity we consider knots and links in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3} as obstacles. We assume that the knots/links are described by polygons, all of which together constitute OâŠ‚â„3ğ‘‚superscriptâ„3O\subset\mathbb{R}^{3}. The thickened obstacles (the knots/links with the tubular neighborhoods) will be referred to as ğ’ªğ’ª\mathcal{O}. We consider a knot/link diagramÂ (Lickorish, 1997) of the obstacles: Given a projection map, p:â„3â†’â„2:ğ‘â†’superscriptâ„3superscriptâ„2p:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{2}, the knot/link diagram is the projection of the knot/link, pâ€‹(O)ğ‘ğ‘‚p(O), along with additional information about the zğ‘§z-ordering at the self-intersections of pâ€‹(O)ğ‘ğ‘‚p(O). We assume that in this diagram the self-intersections are all transverse (which can always be achieved through infinitesimal perturbations) and that the diagram divides the plane into simply-connected regions (say qğ‘q counts of them) each bounded by segments of the projected obstacles, and one unbounded exterior region. The boundary (the boundary of the closure) of each of the bounded regions is itself a polygon, QiâŠ†pâ€‹(O),i=1,2,â‹¯,qformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘–12â‹¯ğ‘Q_{i}\subseteq p(O),~{}i=1,2,\cdots,q (FigureÂ 5(a)). Clearly pâˆ’1â€‹(Qi)âˆ©Osuperscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘‚p^{-1}(Q_{i})\cap O (the preimage of Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} in the original obstacle) will be a discontinuous polygon, with discontinuities at the preimages of the self-intersection points on the knot diagram. But these discontinuities can be removed simply by â€œconnectingâ€ the preimages at each self-intersection point, resulting into a spatial polygon, Q~isubscript~ğ‘„ğ‘–\widetilde{Q}_{i} with the property that pâ€‹(Q~i)=Qiğ‘subscript~ğ‘„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–p(\widetilde{Q}_{i})=Q_{i}. A simple triangulation can then be employed to construct a surface, Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}, in â„3âˆ’Osuperscriptâ„3ğ‘‚\mathbb{R}^{3}-O, such that its boundary is Q~isubscript~ğ‘„ğ‘–\widetilde{Q}_{i} and pâ€‹(Ui)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–p(U_{i}) is the simply-connected region bounded by Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} (this can be achieved by first triangulating the planar region, pâ€‹(Ui)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–p(U_{i}), and then lifting the triangulation to â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}) â€“ see FigureÂ 5(a).

The Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s thus constructed satisfy properties (2) and (3) of PropositionÂ 1, but not property (1), nor do they satisfy the property âˆ‚UiâŠ†âˆ‚Xsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘‹\partial U_{i}\subseteq\partial X. The consequence of this is that near the regions where the Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s intersect, there can be closed loops in â„3âˆ’Osuperscriptâ„3ğ‘‚\mathbb{R}^{3}-O which are null-homotopic, but words constructed simply by tracing the loop and inserting letters corresponding to intersections with the Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s, as we did earlier, may not be the empty word (identity element). An example is illustrated in FigureÂ 5(b)). Due to our construction, such intersection of the Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s happen only along lines passing through the pre-image of the self-intersections in the knot diagram, for each of which we end up getting a null-homotopic closed loop with non-empty word.

The Dehn presentationÂ (Weinbaum, 1971) uses surfaces as constructed to describe the fundamental group of knot/link complements. 3.2 The Word Problem and Dehn Algorithm

Due to the discussion above, two trajectories, Î³1,Î³2subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ›¾2\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}, connecting xssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ x_{s} and xesubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘’x_{e} in the knot/link complement, Xğ‘‹X, belong to the same homotopy class iff the word h(Î³1âˆªâˆ’Î³2)=h(Î³1)âˆ˜h(Î³2)âˆ’1h(\gamma_{1}\cup-\gamma_{2})=h(\gamma_{1})\circ h(\gamma_{2})^{-1} belongs to N=<ğ‘Â¯G>ğ‘expectationsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğºN=<\!\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}^{G}\!>. This problem in group theory is known as the word problemÂ (Epstein, 1992), and there are various algorithms, each suitable for specific types of groups, for solving the word problem. We, in particular, will focus on a very simple algorithm due to Max DehnÂ (Lyndon and Schupp, 2001; Greendlinger and Greendlinger, 1986), which is applicable to a wide class of groups and their presentations.

Dehnâ€™s metric algorithm: Given a presentation of a group, Ï€1=<ğ”|ğ‘>subscriptğœ‹1inner-productğ”ğ‘\pi_{1}=<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!>, we construct the symmetricized relation set ğ‘Â¯Â¯ğ‘\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} as described earlier. Given a cyclically reduced word, wğ‘¤w, made up of letters (and their inverses) from ğ”ğ”\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}, one checks for every element Ïâˆˆğ‘Â¯ğœŒÂ¯ğ‘\rho\in\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} if wğ‘¤w and ÏğœŒ\rho share a common sub-words that is of length greater than |Ï|/2ğœŒ2|\rho|/2 (|Ï|ğœŒ|\rho| being the length of ÏğœŒ\rho). If they do (say, Ï=Î±â€‹Î²â€‹Î³ğœŒğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾\rho=\alpha\beta\gamma, with Î²ğ›½\beta being a sub-word appearing in wğ‘¤w, and |Î²|>|Ï|/2ğ›½ğœŒ2|\beta|>|\rho|/2), we replace the sub-word with the shorter equivalent that one obtains by setting ÏğœŒ\rho to the identity element (i.e., replace Î²ğ›½\beta by Î±âˆ’1â€‹Î³âˆ’1superscriptğ›¼1superscriptğ›¾1\alpha^{-1}\gamma^{-1} in wğ‘¤w). This process is repeated, and the algorithm terminates when no more such sub-words are found. The final word at which the algorithm terminates indicates if the initial word, wğ‘¤w, is in Nğ‘N (whether it maps to the identity element in Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1}).

This algorithm can be used in conjunction with search in Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h} as before for finding optimal trajectories in different homotopy classes, with two vertices (x,w1),(x,w2)âˆˆVhğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ‘‰â„(x,w_{1}),(x,w_{2})\in V_{h} being the same iff hâ€‹(w1)âˆ˜hâ€‹(âˆ’w2)â„subscriptğ‘¤1â„subscriptğ‘¤2h(w_{1})\circ h(-w_{2}) reduces to the empty word upon applying the Dehnâ€™s metric algorithm.

3.3 Guarantees of Dehn Algorithm

Itâ€™s well known (Greendlinger and Greendlinger, 1986) that if Dehn algorithm terminates at the empty word, then wâˆˆNğ‘¤ğ‘w\in N. However, the converse is not necessarily true. One can derive several sufficient (and often highly restrictive) conditions on the presentation <ğ”|ğ‘>inner-productğ”ğ‘<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!> under which the converse holds (Lyndon and Schupp, 2001). If, for a given presentation of a group the converse holds, we say that Dehn algorithm is complete for that presentation (or that the presentation is complete with respect to the Dehn algorithm, or that the word problem is solvable using the specific presentation and Dehn algorithm).

Due to the result of (Weinbaum, 1971), the Dehn presentation of the fundamental groups of the complement of a tame, alternating, prime knot is complete with respect to the Dehn algorithm. It is also knownÂ (Epstein, 1992) that automatic groups (including hyperbolic groups) have presentations that are complete with respect to Dehn algorithm.

4 Cylindrically-deleted Configuration Spaces

The previous results are limited to 3-dimensional spaces: one suspects that higher dimensions are more difficult. However, there are some classes of spaces for which optimal path-planning with homotopy constraints is still computable via a Dehn algorithm, independent of dimension. The following class of examples is inspired by robot coordination problems, in which individual agents with predetermined motion paths have to coordinate their motions so as to avoid collision.

Consider a collection of nğ‘›n graphs (Î“i)1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptÎ“ğ‘–1ğ‘›(\Gamma_{i})_{1}^{n}, each embedded in a common workspace (usually â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} or â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}) with intersections permitted. In the simplest case, each Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i} will be homeomorphic to a closed interval, but more general graphs are permitted, such as roadmap approximations to a configuration space. On each Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i}, a robot Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{i} with some particular fixed size/shape is free to move. Such motion may be Euclidean (by translation/rotation); more general motions are possible, so long as the region occupied by the robot Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{i} in the workspace is purely a function of location on Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i}. A point in the product space âˆiÎ“isubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘–\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} determines the locations of the nğ‘›n robots in the common workspace. Certain configurations are illegal, due to collisions. For example, if the robots are point-like, and each Î“i=Î“subscriptÎ“ğ‘–Î“\Gamma_{i}=\Gamma is identical, then the configuration space of nğ‘›n points on Î“Î“\Gamma is the cross product âˆiÎ“isubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘–\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} minus the pairwise diagonal Î”Î”\Delta. If the robots are given finite extent, then this system has a configuration space obtained by the graph product âˆiÎ“isubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘–\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} minus an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-neighborhood of the pairwise diagonal. However, more general types of collisions can be defined, say, if the robots are irregularly shaped and the graphs Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i} are all different. In this most general case, the natural analogue of a configuration space is the coordination spaces of (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006).

The coordination space of this system is defined to be the space of all configurations in âˆiÎ“isubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘–\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} for which there are no collisions â€“ the geometric robots Risubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–R_{i} have no overlaps in the workspace. Under the assumption that collisions between robots are pairwise-defined, the coordination space is cylindrically deleted and of the form

X=(âˆi=1nÎ“i)âˆ’ğ’ªâ€‹whereâ€‹ğ’ª=â‹ƒi<j{(xk)1Nâˆˆâˆk=1NÎ“k:(xi,xj)âˆˆÎ”i,j},ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptÎ“ğ‘–ğ’ªwhereğ’ªsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptÎ“ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—X=\left(\prod_{i=1}^{n}\Gamma_{i}\right)-{\mathcal{O}}\quad{\rm where}\quad{\mathcal{O}}=\bigcup_{i<j}\left\{(x_{k})_{1}^{N}\in\prod_{k=1}^{N}\Gamma_{k}\,:\,(x_{i},x_{j})\in\Delta_{i,j}\right\},

for some (open, â€œcollisionâ€) sets Î”i,jâŠ‚Î“iÃ—Î“jsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptÎ“ğ‘–subscriptÎ“ğ‘—\Delta_{i,j}\subset\Gamma_{i}\times\Gamma_{j} where 1â‰¤i<jâ‰¤N1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq i<j\leq N. In what follows, we assume that the Î”i,jsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘—\Delta_{i,j} are sufficiently tame (e.g., semialgebraic) so as to avoid issues of non-finitely-generated Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1}. Given (internal, path-) metrics on each Î“isubscriptÎ“ğ‘–\Gamma_{i}, the coordination space Xğ‘‹X inherits a locally-Euclidean metric on products of edges in the graphs. Such Xğ‘‹X are complete path-spaces and thus the problem of geodesics is well-posed. Their fundamental groups can be (highly) nontrivial, depending on the obstacle set ğ’ªğ’ª{\mathcal{O}}. However, finding optimal paths subject to homotopy classes is still computable. To that end one can construct the subspaces UiâŠ‚Xsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘‹U_{i}\subset X of co-dimension 111, and the relation set ğ‘ğ‘\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}, and use them to design complete homotopy invariants as before. We do not discuss the explicit construction of the Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}â€™s for cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces in this paper, but provide the following theorem on solvability of the word problem in such spaces.

Theorem 1

Any compact cylindrically-deleted coordination space Xğ‘‹X admits a Dehn algorithm for Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1}.

Proof.Â  Any such Xğ‘‹X is realized as a Hausdorff limit of cubcial complexes which were shown in (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006, Thm 4.4) to be nonpositively-curved and to stabilize in Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1} by tameness. All nonpositively-curved piecewise-Euclidean cube complexes have fundamental groups which are, by a famous result of Niblo-Reeves (Niblo and Reeves, 1998), biautomatic. Biautomatic groups all admit a Dehn algorithm (specifically, there is a quadratic isoperimetric inequality) (Epstein, 1992).
qed. â–¡â–¡\square

It is worth noting that â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-shortest paths are perhaps not the most natural optimization for coordination spaces. It would be interesting to consider other (â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}, â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}) pointwise norms.

In the next section we consider point robots navigating on a plane. The configuration space of each robot is the Euclidean plane. For such a configuration space for the individual robots, the result of TheoremÂ 1 may not hold, since the fundamental group of the coordination space may not be biautomatic. Nevertheless, we can construct a presentation of the fundamental group, which we do, and still apply Dehn metric algorithm to it, although the Dehn algorithm may not be complete for the proposed presentation.

4.1 Presentation of the Fundamental Group of a Cylindrically Deleted Coordination Space for Point Robots Navigating on a Plane

We consider point robots navigating on a plane. 4.1.3 Explicit Example for N=3ğ‘3N=3

5 Simulation Results

5.1 Knot and Link Complements

Given obstacles ğ’ªâŠ‚â„3ğ’ªsuperscriptâ„3\mathcal{O}\subset\mathbb{R}^{3}, and their â€œskeletonsâ€ (111-dimensional homotopy equivalents), OâŠ†ğ’ªğ‘‚ğ’ªO\subseteq\mathcal{O} as polygons in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}, we first choose a projection map, p:â„3â†’â„2:ğ‘â†’superscriptâ„3superscriptâ„2p:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{2}, for the knot/link diagram. With this information, we implemented the automated construction of the surfaces, Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}, for the Dehn presentation of the knot/link complement, and the symmetricized relation set, ğ‘Â¯Â¯ğ‘\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}, by computing the self-intersections in pâ€‹(O)ğ‘ğ‘‚p(O). We then used a uniform cubical discretization of â„3âˆ’ğ’ªsuperscriptâ„3ğ’ª\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O} to construct the graph GğºG as a discrete representation of the free space, and in the hâ„h-augmented graph, Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h}, we find trajectories from (xs,â€œâ€‹â€)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ â€œâ€(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''}) to (xg,âˆ—)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘”(x_{g},*). We then employ a curve shortening algorithm to shorten the obtained trajectories. All our implementations were done in C++ programming language and visualization were done using OpenGL. The program ran on a laptop running on a Intel i7-4500U processor @ 1.80GHz with 8 GB memory.

FigureÂ 8(a) shows results in the complement of a trefoil knot. The inset figure shows the surfaces, Uisubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–U_{i}, used for Dehn presentation. The graph GğºG was constructed out of uniform 100Ã—100Ã—100100100100100\!\times\!100\!\times\!100 cubical discretization of the environment. As seen in the figure, using the proposed search-based algorithm we computed 555 shortest paths in different homotopy classes and used curve-shortening algorithms to shorten them to obtain the piece-wise linear paths. The entire computation (computation of the surfaces, the symmetricized relation set ğ‘ğ‘\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}, and computation of the 555 shortest trajectories) required about 8.18.18.1â€‰s. Likewise, FigureÂ 8(b) shows results in the complement of a simple Hopf link, with the same discretization of the environment, and total computation time of about 8.28.28.2â€‰s.

FigureÂ 8(c) shows a much more complex obstacle involving a torus knot linked to a genus-222 obstacle, and the entire computation of 202020 trajectories took about 2.62.62.6â€‰s. While in a complex space as this, the completeness of Dehn algorithm is not guaranteed, numerical computation still gives us reasonable results as can be seen in this simulation result.

It is interesting to observe that computing shortest paths in 555 different classes in the environments of FiguresÂ 8(a) and 8(b) took significantly longer than the computation of 202020 classes in the environment of FigureÂ 8(c). This is because in FigureÂ 8(c), although much more complex, the obstacles themselves occupy a large part of the environment. This significantly reduces the number of vertices and edges in the discrete graph representing the free configuration space than the trefoil knot and Hopf link complements. Thus the graph search runs much faster in the configuration space of FigureÂ 8(c).

5.2 Coordination Space of 333 Robots Navigating on a Plane

Similar to the method described in SectionÂ 2.5, we implemented the graph search based approach for finding optimal paths in the coordination space of 333 robots navigating on a planar region. We constructed a graph using a uniform hyper-cubical discretization of the configuration space, Î“Â¯=â„6Â¯Î“superscriptâ„6\overline{\Gamma}=\mathbb{R}^{6}, placing a vertex in each cell, and establishing edges between neighboring cells that correspond to robot motions parallel to the coordinate axes. The optimality criteria in the A* search was chosen to be the sum of the total lengths of the paths (which, because of the chosen discretization, is the length due to the Manhattan metric on the plane) traversed by the robots. The hâ„h-augmented graph construction from this graph is similar to what has been described in SectionÂ 2.5. However for checking whether or not two hâ„h-signatures are the same, we use the Dehn algorithm on the presentation described in ExampleÂ 4.1.3.

FigureÂ 9 (also, in attached multimedia file) shows paths found in 555 different homotopy classes for the coordination space of 333 robots navigating on a plane. With the plane discretized into 7Ã—7777\times 7 grid, and the degree of each vertex in the corresponding joint configuration space being 124124124 (allowing each robot to move north, south, east or west, or stay in place), the computation of paths in 555 different homotopy classes in the coordination space took about 31.731.731.7â€‰s. A careful observation of the figures will indeed reveal that the paths shown in each of the FiguresÂ 9 (a)-(e) correspond to the robots taking distinct homotopy classes in the joint configuration space.

5.3 Some Remarks on Number of Homotopy Classes:

As described earlier, we compute the paths in the different homotopy classes by executing graph search algorithms (Dijkstraâ€™s/A*) on the hâ„h-augmented graph, Ghsubscriptğºâ„G_{h}. As a result we obtain the paths in the different homotopy classes in order of their path lengths/costs. Technically, the number of homotopy classes in any of the configuration spaces described earlier infinite. This is because a path can loop/wind round an obstacle arbitrarily many times, thus creating arbitrarily many different homotopy classes. In the simulations we restrict ourselves to the computation of the first few homotopy classes in each configuration space since those are the classes that are most relevant in robotics applications.

6 Conclusion and Future Work

We presented explicit construction of presentations of the fundamental group of two different classes of spaces: Knot/link complements in Euclidean 333-dimensional spaces, and cylindrically deleted coordination space of multiple robots. We thus used graph search-based optimal path planning method for computing optimal paths in different homotopy classes in such environments. These spaces are highly relevant in many robot motion planning problems, for example unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) navigating inside buildings, and multiple ground robots navigating on a plane. Being able to compute optimal paths in different homotopy classes allow us to efficiently solve motion planning problems for complex systems such as tethered robots and systems involving cables, and design strategies for effectively deploying groups of robots in coverage and exploration tasks.

Moving forward, we will use the developed technique for homotopy path planning in 3-dimensional spaces with obstacles for computing optimal traversable paths for tethered unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). One of the greatest challenges currently faced by UAVs is the limited battery life, which in turn limits the UAVsâ€™ flight time. Having the UAV tethered to a power supply will help alleviate the problem. But in that case one needs to carefully plan paths that satisfy the cable length constraints and prevents the cable from getting tangled in obstacles. Since a real UAV experiment will involve significant amount of investment in terms of equipments, time and development of low-level controllers, we believe an experiment as that is outside the scope of the current paper and will require significant deviation from the theoretical & algorithmic focus of the current paper. We thus propose such an experiment as a future work. But we believe that the new algorithmic tools proposed in this paper will be helpful in solving this real problem in 3-d.
